body: added docs to the PR clarifying behavior of multi-value filtering.

@binlijin @Hailei I agree. To me the most correct thing to do in the case where rhsMetric and lhsMetric == null would be to supply a zero-value. However since the metrics are not typed at this point, this becomes trickier to do in RowboatMergeFunction.apply.  I would like to confirm whether or not a null metric value for this index is a valid solution. @gianm @drcrallen any thoughts?

:+1:

This is a bug in 0.9.0 needs backport
I don't think this de-rails qualification since at MMX we don't have this new feature as part of our qualification process.

I am also in favor of removing the inheritance between IncrementalIndex and IncrementalIndices.

:+1: after travis passes & commits squashed

:+1: after the renaming comment.

@navis out of curiosity do you use this "size" analysis type for anything? I had thought it was not really that useful and I assumed most people issuing segment metadata queries disable it.
@Hailei thats good news, in this case I think setting metrics[i] = null would be a valid solution.
Let me delay my previous :+1: until the comment re: comparator/equals() is addressed

@himanshug @drcrallen @gianm 

I've updated the proposal with:
- note that a single non-boolean filter can only return either a bitmap index or value matcher, but not both (decision is dynamically made)
- more details/examples on boolean filter handling
- description of a new kind of 'ValueMatcher' that uses bitmaps/row offsets during cursor iteration
- filter result caching
rebasing, there are some conflicts with https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2753
Closed by #2369
squashed
looks great thank you @navis

@nicktylah I think we're going to have to rethink a bit more how we want to handle different aws regions. We may also want to consider other things, such as S3 regions to make this a more comprehensive change.
This is not actually a bug, right? It looks like no, so I'm gonna remove the tag.

@gianm Yes, I don't think we can use it meaningfully but it can still make someone happy (UI guys want to show numbers whenever it's possible). By the way I'm thinking of using this to estimate the size of incremental index to be flushed automatically rather than row count. Ah, I've forgot I've already done that in #2459. You can check that if interested.

Is it possible to include a test that would have caught this?

The apply needs more enforcement, from javadocs: ``` java /** * The "extraction" function. This should map a value into some other String value. *

* In order to maintain the "null and empty string are equivalent" semantics that Druid provides, the * empty string is considered invalid output for this method and should instead return null. This is * a contract on the method rather than enforced at a lower level in order to eliminate a global check * for extraction functions that do not already need one. * * @param value the original value of the dimension * * @return a value that should be used instead of the original */ public String apply(Object value); ``` The return value of apply needs `Strings.emptyToNull`
@drcrallen please check this out.
good point @drcrallen
+1, This would be extremely useful.  We use plywood/plyql quite heavily and would like to simplify our query stack if possible.

Can we remove the changes not related to the String null handling?

The code being refactored is being redone in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2760, e.g. those value transformers in IncrementalIndex are removed.
rebased, added extractionFn to new InFilter from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2577 changes

Static config for lookup is eliminated.
Only  `druid.query.extraction.namespace.cache.type` is remained to select type of cache between on/off heap as it is module-wide not per-namespace config.
Addressing comments from @gianm, also going to add more filter tests to this PR

@waltonseymour this would only be true if you have a single historical node, and no realtime nodes or realtime tasks. How many nodes and what kind do you have?

@jon-wei @gianm can we put together a larger issue to aggregate all the null issues you've been seeing lately? It might make sense to have a more comprehensive view of all the issues to help figure out what needs to be done.
@xvrl we agreed for bug fixes and docs a single +1 was required?
@xvrl I've opened an issue here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2778

I'm running it locally, so yes there's only a single historical with no realtime.
Any reason that behavior should be expected?
It might be good to explain why there are 3 resource types (DATASOURCE, CONFIG, STATE)  but 4 ResourceFilters (Datasource, Task, Config, State).
@jon-wei checkout this.

@navis, It was introduced in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2480
can you take a look into it  ?

Should we have some information under Development/ExperimentalFeatures about this feature?  It might be useful to have something written down other than in this PR about what this feature is -  some implementation notes about it, and how it would be used.  
Implementation notes could include saying what endpoints are not protected by authorization, and why not.
I don't think we should hold up this code, but maybe a followup PR?

@waltonseymour this is expected for topN. The broker will rewrite the query to be at least top-1000 from each segment before merging and pruning results. When you query the historical directly that is not the case, instead it's taking the top-5 from each segment, which is going to be very inaccurate. Try setting the top-N threshold to 1000 on the historical, the first 5 results should then match.
